sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a circular loop
message_1: A circular loop of radius 10 cm has a current of 2 A flowing through it. What is the magnetic field at a point 5 cm away from the center of the loop on its axis? (assume the permeability of free space is 4π x 10^-7 T*m/A)
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at a point on the axis of a circular loop, we can use the formula:

B = (μ₀ * I * R²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space, I is the current, R is the radius of the loop, and x is the distance from the center of the loop.

Given the values:
R = 10 cm = 0.1 m
I = 2 A
x = 5 cm = 0.05 m
μ₀ = 4π x 10^(-7) T*m/A

Now we can plug these values into the formula:

B = (4π x 10^(-7) T*m/A * 2 A * (0.1 m)²) / (2 * ((0.1 m)² + (0.05 m)²)^(3/2))

B = (8π x 10^(-7) T*m * 0.01 m²) / (2 * (0.01 m² + 0.0025 m²)^(3/2))

B = (8π x 10^(-9) T*m) / (2 * (0.0125 m²)^(3/2))

B = (8π x 10^(-9) T*m) / (2 * 0.0125^(3/2) m³)

B ≈ (8π x 10^(-9) T*m) / (2 * 0.000555 m³)

B ≈ (8π x 10^(-9) T*m) / (1.11 x 10^(-6) m³)

B ≈ 7.2 x 10^(-3) T

So the magnetic field at a point 5 cm away from the center of the loop on its axis is approximately 7.2 x 10^(-3) T or 7.2 mT.
